title: Discuss the major role of mathematics in information technology? - Quora

response.answer_text: Conditions in code, used for branching and looping, are an example of mathematical logic. Relational databases are based on the mathematical concept of relations. Routing in networks is based on graph theory and Boolean algebra. Cryptography is based on number theory. Artificial intelligence uses statistics. SQL is another example of mathematical logic. The performance of programs is strongly influenced by algorithmic complexity, which is based on algebra. Computers even add with a hardware implementation that uses Boolean algebra. Business models of which projects make sense to do are based on algebra, as are most models of development effort and schedule. Game development involves math related to physics. Business software development often includes math models of finance. Social networks and Excel are based on graph theory. I have personally used transitive closures in graphs and topological sorts of partial orders in graphs in interesting applications. Compilers use trees. Indexes in databases do too.

Some areas of information technology have significantly more math involved than others. For example, video game development with it’s various physics simulations and intense graphics. Software development in general uses a fair amount of math. Network and systems administration use math for calculating IP addresses available in a given network, etc.. Since the fundamentals of information technology operate on logical systems where math is intrinsic to their operations, it may be difficult to find a single area of information technology that does not use math. Before we had digital computers, math mathematicians were kind of like software developers. They could develop a series of formulas and equations that took numbers as the input and delivered numbers as an output to represent some sort of function. This type of math is known as functional programming in software development. Just the other day, I wrote a plugin for a diagram editing application that calculated volume of a contour map. I wrote this plugin in Python and used the diagram editing applications API. Today I wrote a function that delivered an ETA for one of our printing systems. Tomorrow I plan on writing a unit conversion function. In summary, the application of math in information technology is nearly endless.

It really depends on what jobs in IT you're interested in. Some of them require math so much, it would be almost impossible to operate without it, for others a general understanding of the basics would be enough. That is if you're interested in this question because you plan to start a career in IT, you should really look into what knowledge base each specialization requires.

Math is necessary in our everyday lives… IT jobs may or may not need anything higher than the everyday math we use, but it will depend mainly on what exactly you are supposed to do in the IT world. There are at least 20 different job positions in the IT world.. Which one is yours what kind of work can you do??

Discrete mathematics, elements of graph theory, probability and statistics are directly useful in IT, especially for higher levels of IT work, above technician’s routines. Other areas of mathematics, like analysis, geometry and linear algebra are useful indirectly for any intellectual and technically oriented occupation.

Yes definitely! Every aspect of information and data is related to mathematics in one way or the other. Additionally, problems in information technology can be solved using mathematical models which are very efficient compared to others approaches.

I need to go run Cat6 cable 2/3 of the way around a room that is 24ft by 72ft. If I only have 75ft of cable in the supply room, do I have to order more cable before I can start my project? And that is one example of how you use math in IT.
If you want to get a college certificate or degree than you need a few math courses, but I don’t think you need any specially math courses for IT.
